conclusion: Consider contributions from each segment of the wire (AB and BC) separately and then combine them.
The force on a current-carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by: F = I L x B.
For segment AB, the length vector L_AB is along the direction of AB and the magnetic field B_AB is perpendicular to the plane of the paper and pointing inward.
Since L_AB and B_AB are perpendicular, the magnitude of the force on AB is F_AB = I L B.
For segment BC, the length vector L_BC is along the direction of BC and the magnetic field B_BC is perpendicular to the plane of the paper and pointing outward.
Since L_BC and B_BC are perpendicular, the magnitude of the force on BC is F_BC = I L B.
Using the right-hand rule, for segment AB, the force F_AB will be perpendicular to both L_AB and B_AB, pointing out of the plane of the paper.
For segment BC, the force F_BC will be perpendicular to both L_BC and B_BC, pointing into the plane of the paper.
Since the forces F_AB and F_BC are in opposite directions, their magnitudes add up as scalars but their vectors cancel each other out partially due to the angle between them.
The angle between F_AB and F_BC is 120°.
Using the law of cosines for vector addition, F_resultant = sqrt(F_AB^2 + F_BC^2 + 2 F_AB F_BC cos(120°)).
Calculate F_resultant = sqrt(I^2 L^2 B^2 + I^2 L^2 B^2 - I^2 L^2 B^2).
Simplify to F_resultant = sqrt(I^2 L^2 B^2).
The magnitude of the Ampere force received by the wire is I L B.
